Award.AwardTitle: Study on singlet oxygen-mediated oxidation mechanism, dynamics and consequences of the guanine base of DNA using gas- and solution-phase techniques and dynamics simulations
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms (CSDM-A) Program of the Division of Chemistry is funding Professor Jianbo Liu of CUNY Queens College to study the reaction of an excited form of oxygen with the guanine base of DNA. Oxygen damage to guanine is a key chemical step with biological consequences that range from photocleavage, mutagenesis and carcinogenesis to cellular lethality. Specifically, the oxidation products are involved in the basic chemistry of neurological disorders such as Alzheimer's and Parkinson's diseases. This project will investigate the oxidation mechanisms in different environments, and will determine the consequences of guanine oxidative modifications on base pairing and DNA-protein cross-links. The project also has a strong educational component, bringing undergraduate and graduate students into the research laboratory. This is expected to help broaden participation as Queens College serves a large number (40%) of first generation college students; about half of these are of minority background.

The project uses electrospray mass spectrometry (ESI-MS) and guided-ion-beam scattering to probe the singlet oxygen oxidation of guanine and its derivatives in the gas phase. Reaction cross sections are measured as a function of collision energy for protonated/deprotonated guanine ions and for guanine ions clustering with water. Following the gas-phase experiments, the same systems are to be investigated in aqueous solutions using on-line spectroscopy and ESI-MS/MS. The other major experimental thrust is to study the consequences of guanine oxidation on its base pairing with cytosine and on cross-linking reactions with lysine. These experiments are complemented by electronic structure calculations of reaction coordinates, RRKM modeling of complex mediated pathways, and trajectory simulations of dynamics behaviors. These studies are directed at exploring and elucidating the mechanism of these singlet oxygen reactions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Singlet oxygen is a highly reactive oxygen species that can be generated in nature and within biological systems from normal oxygen molecules we are breathing.  Of the four DNA nucleobases, guanine is the exclusive target for singlet oxygen attack.  The singlet oxygen oxidatively generated damage to guanine may lead to mutagenesis, carcinogenesis and celluar lethality.  Specifically, the damage is related to DNA-protein cross-linking, mispairing of oxidized guanine with adenine during replication, and neurological disorders for Alzheimer's and Parkinson's diseases.  Understanding how the chemical reactions of guanine nucleobase with singlet oxygen change the functions of and destroy DNA could make it possible to design procedures for slowing down oxidatively generated damage to the living things.  Paradoxically, because singlet oxygen oxidizes and destroys biomolecules, it could be harnessed for positive ends, for example, as the driving force in photodynamic therapy to kill cancer cells.  The goal of this project was to utilize mass spectrometry, molecular spectroscopy and parallel gas- and solution-phase reaction techniques, in conjunction with computational modeling, to explore singlet oxygen oxidation mechanisms, reaction kinetics and reaction dynamics of guanine and its derivatives, and the consequences of guanine oxidative modification on base-pairing and DNA-protein cross-linking.  The following highlights results from specific studies.  

We first measured the oxidation reactions of isolated guanine, 9-methylguanine (a prototype model of guanosine) and 8-oxo-guanine (an oxidized derivative of guanine) in the gas phase using a home-made electrospray ionization guided-ion-beam scattering tandem mass spectrometer.  Quantitative measurements were carried out on the effects of collision energy, protonation/deprotonation and charge states, and modifications of base structure on reaction products, reaction thermodynamics and reaction rates.  Gas-phase experiments have distinguished the intrinsic reactivities of guanine reactants from the solvent and counter-ions effects, and revealed the different and sometime contrasting oxidation chemistry between protonated and deprotonated guanine reactants.  These findings have provided a basis for understanding guanine oxidation mechanisms.  

We then investigated the gas-phase reactions of guanine-cytosine base pairs in their protonated and deprotonated forms.  An unexpected yet very intriguing "non-statistical" dissociation of guanine-cytosine base pairs was discovered.  The experimental and theoretical study of this phenomena has provided considerable insight into base pair tautomerization, intra-base-pair proton transfer and their entangling with single oxygen oxidation chemistry of the guanine moiety contained within.  

Finally, we studied the oxidation kinetics of guanine and 9-methylguanine in aqueous solution, using a home-made on-line kinetics monitoring system which coupled real-time spectroscopy measurements with mass spectrometry.  Our gas-phase experiments focused on revealing the early-stage oxidation dynamics; our solution-phase measurements, on the other hand, determined the late-stage reaction kinetics (including measurements of reaction rate constants and end products) and consequences of guanine oxidation (such as cross-linking of the oxidized guanine base with lysine residues, referred to as DNA-protein cross-linking).  Combination of gas- and solution-phase results, augmented by computational modeling of reaction potential energy surfaces, kinetics and dynamics, produced unprecedented detailed information for the oxidation mechanisms of guanine in different environments.  A quantitative picture was provided for the formation, structures and transformations of oxidation intermediates during the singlet oxygen oxidation of guanine.

All of our work were published in peer reviewed scientific journals and presented at major conferences.  Besides the fundamental importance of understanding biomolecule oxidation mechanisms and their biological implications, the present research has developed new mass spectrometric and spectroscopic techniques for examining singlet oxygen chemistry in the gas phase and in solution.

Queens College of the City University of New York is a Minority Serving Institution.  Our students represent a wide range of background, with half come from under-represented groups in science.  This project generated significant educational benefits.  Broader impacts included training three doctoral graduate students (their dissertation research were supported by this grant), four Master's graduate students and six undergraduate research students in the areas of experimental and theoretical chemistry and instrumentation development.  The project has initiated research collaboration with a community college to integrate the community college faculty and students into the CUNY research community.  The project was also integrated to the Instrumental Analysis course teaching, with large efforts devoted to curriculum innovation and laboratory modernization.
